content: I show you my stuff with DM Scotty hey guys welcome to I show you my stuff
at DM Scotty today I'm going to show you something interesting it's actually some
3d buildings that I've done and then most of them are out of cardstock I've
added some other details a little foam and some wood and some sculpt Lian one
uh but most like you know 90% of the 90 95 percent of the of the building itself
is made out of cardboard and cardstock so these are really easy to make and
they look really really good um the only thing with this method is you know when
you make us any kind of 3d structure takes a lot of time a lot more time than
just doing a tile so if I was going to do a whole city section I probably
wouldn't do all the buildings unless I had months and months and months to
prepare for that but occasionally it can be fun to have like a 3d building if you
have a lone cottage or smaller location that you can model in 3d another thing I
found with 3d buildings that I've always been kind of irked about is that it's
always difficult to play inside the buildings because though I feel they do
it wrong what they've got is they've got you take the roof off then you've got
all the walls and usually it's a small space and you're trying to reach in
there and move your guys around and you really can't it's hard to manipulate
everything so what I've done is I've taken the title method and use it on 3d
buildings so it's kind of flipped so instead of taking the roof off and then
you have the walls you just take the whole building off and you've got the
tile and you got it you can even preset up the tile with everything you want on
it when you take a building off there they you know that there it is they see
it so this is a great method for making you know for making 3d buildings but
also utilizing the 2.5 D tiles also so I've got some great examples at my table
so let's go to my table I'll show you what I came up with so here's one of the
colleges I made and as you can see it is a 3d cottage but it's all a lot of
cardboard so but there's a trick to this cottage you can see I have a couple
peasants out here for scale one of the tricks I like to do when I built
cottages like this is a I think figures might end up on the roof
I make the roof the pitch not steep enough so that the figures will fall off
so that's a good little tip you can do but the second trick is really to use
the DMS craft method of tiles inside of buildings what how they do it with
normal 3d buildings is they usually I think they get it wrong what they do is
they they have the walls to the building so it's very difficult to reach inside
the building but I do it totally differently instead of having the walls
inside the building I've got a tile underneath and I reveal the tile by
lifting off the 3d piece so if you lift off this cottage you can see I've got
all the insides of the cottage already preset and so when the players come in
or whatever you know they'll be inside the cottage so that's a nice way that
give you access to the inside of the tile without having all the 3d walls
that you're bumping into trying to reach in there and grab and move this stuff so
I thought that came out really nice um now I want to talk a little bit about
more about you've seen me do my tiles and everything but I wanted to show you
that little trick and we have talked about this on my forms but I want to
share some of the others that may have not have seen this also let me move this
aside we'll talk them a little more about the house so the house itself is
just a box that I've taken and cut I put the pitch of the roof there I put
a piece of cardboard for the pitch of the roof all this kind of boarding on
the side is just all cardstock now I made the shutters and the door broken up
because this this cottage was attacked by a werewolf so you can see that really
there it's broken into and everything so but all this is just cardboard and
cardstock the roof the thatched roof is just glue glue the glue gun just
dragging the glue gun and lines across the top now the the chimney itself is
kind of neat I did this out of a thin piece of styrofoam and I use the hot
wire foam three and did the stones on it but you
could easily paint you could easily do a cardboard chimney you wouldn't have to
do this I just had access to the tools so I did it and the top little things on
the top are just some beads that I glued on top so but I think that looking about
really really nice for just being out of cardboard it's all out of cardboard and
cardstock except for the chimney now I'm going to show you another version that I
did and I'll come back for that this one is pretty interesting it's
actually a mill and as you can see it's a two-level deal so I've got a little
guy here for scale but let me so this can come off this top comes off and then
I've got an interior for the top there let me take this stuff off so that I can
show you pick it up and show you more of the detail okay and you can see on the
back here I've got a wheel and this was actually in the water I had a river
going past this and this was in the water so move this aside so here's the
other house it's very similar to the first one I showed you I did do a little
vent hole here as opposed to the chimney but I did the kind of cross-hatched
windows that you might see on a medieval building I've did painted a different
color but I did that would work with the with the card stock to give it that
medieval look and then you can see there's a side in the back so this one
wasn't destroyed previous to the fight so so just the same techniques on that
now the bottom was giving me a look at the bottom so I've got two doors going
into it on the bottom and I did like stonework around the the bottom part of
this and then here's the the wheel for the water wheel I had now for when I
turn it over I use some wood to hold the top layer up you could use card stock
but I had the wood so I went ahead and use that now one cool thing about this
encounter was when the players came up the ogres were rating this rating this
mill for for grain and what they did is they ripped this waterwheel off okay
and they actually threw it at the player so it goes rolling I'd actually hit a
couple players they got caught in the wheel and they rolled with it for a
while until they were able to get out of it so that was a kind of a fun encounter
now in the bottom of this I didn't put the other one under the bottom of this
but it works just the same way as the top so turn around so you can see the
doors so you would come in the doors here it'd be like that
and then you lift it off and then you can see I've got a grinding wheel here I
did these is just some boxes for the they were storing the grain in so the
grinding wheel was just made out of some wood you can see the wood post and it
would post come out of here and then these pieces the grinding wheel pieces
themselves were made out of super skull plate so I just sculpted it into the
shape of the grinding wheel and then baked it and then painted it up like
stone so they gave a really nice appearance we had a pretty tense moment
we played this encounter one of the odors ended up grabbing one of the
players and putting their head down of the wheel and was going to squish their
head under the wheel and luckily one of the warrior cared I ran and head-butted
the ogre with his spiked helmet and was able to knock the ogre off go off
balance and the save that save their friends so that was a pretty tense
encounter but they got through it so yeah that's this is a cool way that
you can do 3d type buildings but still use the DMS craft tile method so I like
it because it doesn't with the wall here it'd be very hard to reach in there and
move the guys around but with the wall but they're all gone
it's really you know gives ease of access of play and then if you do want
to do some 3d stuff at your table just make it outta cardboard and card stock
like we've done everything else oh let me talk about the roof for a second now
the roof you can see has has individual tiles which is it looks a lot better
than how hard it was to make it was very easy to make so I just made half inch
strips and then I turned the cardboard over and I took a an ink pen and dragged
it along the core between the corrugations so ripped between each
corrugation and gave that really cool texture
looking like tiles on the roof and I just blew these strips on the roof and
voila you know I've got my tiled roof so thought that really came out nice all
right there you go there's some more of my stuff and I'll see you next time on I
show you my stuff hey crafters I hope you've enjoyed this episode of the DMS
craft make sure to subscribe and I have tons of other videos as you can see I am
the originator of the 2.5 D method of crafting tiles I also do dirt cheap
terrain for the table if all this intrigues you make sure you check out
all the videos below also join my forum we have lots of great crafters on there
who give advice I have a link above and below and last but not least remember go
forth and draft you
